intro: Pelea brighamii, commonly known as Brigham's pelea, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its delicate, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in arid environments. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
